description: From Middle English palmestrie. Equivalent to palm +‎ -ist +‎ -ry.

entries.meaning: Telling fortunes from the lines on the palms of the hand.
examples: Chiromantie is a coniecturyng by beholdyng the lynes, or wryncles of the handes called commonly Palmistry.

entries.meaning: (countable) A book on palmistry; a system of palmistry.
examples: The bird-runes on the stretched silk of her hand

entries.meaning: (obsolete, rare) A dexterous use or trick of the hand.
examples: In the Height of his Good-humour, meeting a common Beggar upon the Road who was no Conjuror, as he went to relieve him he found his Pocket was pick’d: That being a Kind of Palmistry at which this Race of Vermin are very dextrous.
